body.body: Oil is collected from the sump and is drawn through a mesh strainer into the oil pump rotor. The oil pump is fitted with a single pumping rotor which supplies pressurised oil to the lubrication circuit and the oil cooler.
Pressurised oil is delivered to the outside rim of the oil filter near to where the oil pressure relief valve is fitted. The relief valve is set to open at 75 lb/in
and when open, returns high pressure oil direct to the sump.
Filtered oil is then fed via the remote oil cooler (mounted beneath the radiator) into the lower crankcase gallery and is then distributed around the engine:
Cooled oil is fed to the main gallery located under the crankshaft. It is delivered to the crankshaft main bearings and, via drillings in the crankshaft, to the big end bearings.
Spray jets located in the upper crankcase, behind the main bearing shells, lubricate the pistons and connecting rod small ends. These jets are fed oil from the crankshaft oil feed.

Some oil is sent directly to the cylinder head via a drilling in the upper crankcase and an external link pipe. A low oil pressure warning light switch is located at the crankcase end of the link pipe. Oil that arrives at the cylinder head is fed to both camshafts via a gallery in the cylinder head casting that delivers oil directly to the sprocket end camshaft bearings. Oil is then fed through the hollow camshafts to the other camshaft bearings, the tappet buckets and the valves.

Oil is fed to the gearbox via internal oil pipes and drillings that supply oil directly to the end of each shaft. Oil is circulated along the gearbox shafts to exit holes that feed directly to the bearings, gears and selectors.
Oil is fed to the alternator to aid cooling. The oil is taken from the crankshaft oil feed and directed to the alternator via a drilling in an oil feed bolt located in the crankcase.
